abstracts.cdata!:
The overall project outcome is assessed
            as satisfactory, and project sustainability is likely. Both
            World Bank and Borrower performances are adjudged
            satisfactory. Lessons learned included the following:
            Experience from the project shows that outsourcing design
            and supervision to a unit staffed by professionals or
            consultants, and centralizing the planning and financing,
            can ensure project readiness for implementation, and reduce
            the time lag between project design and implementation.
            Also, this approach enhances cost-effectiveness. A number of
            constraints remain to be addressed if the local contracting
            industry is to be sustained, and they include the
            incompatibility of fixed rate contracts in a fluctuating
            macroeconomic environment, the review of bidding
            requirements, the long time lag between tendering and
            awarding of contract which may require changes in the nature
            of maintenance works, and the elimination of risks due to
            uncertainty of payments for works performed. Long-term
            partnership of the donor community with the Government is
            critical to the sustainable development of the transport
            sector in Uganda. The implementation experience from this
            project has highlighted the need and urgency of
            institutional reforms if investments in the road sector are
            to provide the expected impact. The consolidation of
            institutional reforms would be a major task of follow-on
            projects, if the absorptive capacity of the transport sector
            is to be significantly improved.

18157452.theme: Other financial and private sector development,Infrastructure services for private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Project's overall objectives
            are to assist the Government of Uganda in providing the
            basic road infrastructure to the economy, and ensuring that
            this and the rail/ferry infrastructure will be well
            maintained and efficiently managed, with private sector
            involvement wherever practicable. The project will: a)
            protect the capital investment in, and increase the service
            life of, selected rehabilitated roads; b) improve
            maintenance planning and operations of the main road
            network; c) improve Ministry of Works, Transport and
            Communications' capability for project implementation;
            d) introduce labor-based methods of road maintenance and
            feeder roads rehabilitation whenever most cost-effective; e)
            improve Ministry of Local Government's and District
            Authorities' capacity to plan, manage and monitor
            feeder roads rehabilitation and maintenance; f) improve
            feeder roads accessibility; g) train, advise and employ
            domestic small and medium contractors for roads works; h)
            reorient Uganda Railways Corporation's management
            towards commercial operation and promote its financial autonomy.
